senses.definition: a thing that you do for interest or pleasure

examples.x: leisure/outdoor/recreational activities
The club provides a wide variety of activities including tennis, swimming and squash.

senses.definition: a thing that somebody does in order to achieve a particular aim

examples.x: criminal/terrorist/illegal activities
The book contains plenty of ideas for classroom activities.
He has decided to focus his time and resources on his business activities.
We met to review progress and to coordinate our activities.

senses.definition: a situation in which something is happening or a lot of things are being done

examples.x: Economic activity has taken a downturn this year.
The streets were noisy and full of activity.
Muscles contract and relax during physical activity.
There was no criminal activity involved.
The machines can monitor brain activity.

senses.definition: the activity of producing and acting in plays for the theatre, by people who do it for pleasure, not as a job
a person who catches fish (= goes angling) as a hobby
the art or sport of catching fish with a fishing rod hunting

examples.x: modern/contemporary art
an art critic/historian/lover

stolen works of art

American art

senses.definition: examples of objects such as paintings, drawings or sculptures art galleries

examples.x: an art gallery/exhibition

senses.definition: the skill of creating objects such as paintings and drawings, especially when you study it make

examples.x: She's good at art and design.

an art teacher/student/college/class

senses.definition: art, music, theatre, literature, etc. when you think of them as a group

senses.definition: the subjects you can study at school or university that are not sciences, such as languages, history or literature

senses.definition: the study of the positions of the stars and the movements of the planets in the belief that they influence human affairs

examples.x: I read the horoscopes for fun but I don’t really believe in astrology.

senses.definition: a type of dancing done with a partner and using particular fixed steps and movements to particular types of music such as the waltz

to go up something towards the top

examples.x: to climb a mountain/tree

As they climbed higher, the air became cooler.

senses.definition: to go up mountains or climb rocks as a hobby or sport

examples.x: He likes to go climbing most weekends.

senses.definition: to move somewhere, especially with difficulty or effort, using hands as well as feet

examples.x: I climbed through the window.

Can you climb down?

senses.definition: to increase in value or amount

examples.x: The death toll from the devastating floods continues to climb.

senses.definition: to move to a higher position in a chart, table, society or organization

examples.x: The team has now climbed to fourth in the league.

senses.definition: to go higher in the sky

examples.x: The plane climbed to 33 000 feet.

senses.definition: to slope upwards

examples.x: From here the path climbs steeply to the summit.

senses.definition: to grow up a wall or frame

senses.definition: the activity of going to nightclubs regularly

to write poetry
a poetry reading
Maya Angelou’s poetry
a book/collection/anthology of poetry

senses.definition: a quality of beauty, style and feeling

examples.x: There was poetry in all her gestures.

senses.definition: the activity of riding ponies in the countryside for pleasure

examples.x: to go pony-trekking

senses.definition: the art of making portraits; the portraits that are made
pots, dishes, etc. made with clay that are baked in an oven, especially when they are made by hand

examples.x: Roman pottery
a piece of pottery
fragments of Iron Age pottery
the kilns in which the pottery is fired

senses.definition: the clay that some dishes and pots are made of

examples.x: a jug made of blue-glazed pottery
a pottery casserole dish

senses.definition: the skill of making pots and dishes from clay, especially by hand

examples.x: a pottery class

senses.definition: a place where clay pots and dishes are made
to walk for pleasure, especially in the countryside

examples.x: We spent the summer rambling in Ireland.
You can ramble through some beautiful countryside in the area.

senses.definition: to talk about somebody/something in a confused way, especially for a long time

examples.x: He had lost track of what he was saying and began to ramble.
What is she rambling on about now?

senses.definition: to grow in many different directions, especially over other plants or objects

examples.x: Climbing plants rambled over the front of the house.

senses.definition: a long walk for pleasure

examples.x: to go for a ramble in the country
We went for a ramble over the moors.

senses.definition: a long confused speech or piece of writing

examples.x: She went into a long ramble about the evils of television.

senses.definition: the activity of walking for pleasure in the countryside

examples.x: She’s a member of a rambling club.

senses.definition: speech or writing that continues for a long time without saying much and seems very confused

examples.x: the ramblings of a madman

senses.definition: the activity of somebody who reads

examples.x: My hobbies include reading and painting.
He needs more help with his reading.
Are you any good at map reading?
He enjoys reading and going to the cinema.
reading glasses (= worn when reading)
a reading lamp/light (= one that can be moved to shine light onto something that you are reading)
She has a reading knowledge of German (= she can understand written German).
After extensive reading on the subject she set to work on an article.
He's done a lot of reading about the history of the town.

senses.definition: an act of reading something

examples.x: A closer (= more detailed) reading of the text reveals just how desperate he was feeling.
We are all expected to attend the reading of her will.

senses.definition: books, articles, etc. that are intended to be read

examples.x: reading material
reading matter
a series of reading books for children
further reading (= at the end of a book, a list of other books that give more information about the same subject)
The report makes for interesting reading (= it is interesting to read)
The article is not exactly light reading (= it is serious and requires effort and concentration to understand).
His article should be compulsory reading for law students.
Her assigned reading for English class was ‘Great Expectations’.
a list of suggested reading on this topic

senses.definition: the particular way in which you understand a book, situation, etc.

examples.x: Those conclusions are based on a literal reading of the text.
My own reading of events is less optimistic.

senses.definition: the amount or number shown on an instrument used for measuring something

examples.x: Meter readings are taken every three months.

senses.definition: an event at which something is read to an audience for entertainment; a piece of literature that is read at such an event

examples.x: He was invited to give a poetry reading as part of the literary festival.
The evening ended with a reading from her latest novel.

senses.definition: a short section from a holy text that is read to people as part of a religious service

examples.x: The reading today is from the Book of Daniel.
readings from the Koran

senses.definition: one of the stages during which a bill (= a proposal for a new law) must be discussed and accepted by a parliament before it can become law

examples.x: The bill looks like it will be given a second reading.

senses.definition: to rest while you are doing something that you enjoy, especially after work or effort

examples.x: Just relax and enjoy the movie.
I'm going to spend the weekend just relaxing.
He was relaxing at home, watching TV.
She finished her lunch and then relaxed in the sun.
The boys had been relaxing on the beach at their resort.
You need a little time to relax and unwind.
When I get home from work I like to relax with the newspaper.
Sit back and relax with a cup of tea.

senses.definition: to become or make somebody become calmer and less worried

examples.x: I'll only relax when I know you're safe.
I can't relax until I've spoken to her myself.
'You need to try and relax,' Jane said.
Relax! Everything will be OK.
A herbal tea will relax you.

senses.definition: to become or make something become less tight or stiff

examples.x: Allow your muscles to relax completely.
The massage relaxed my tense back muscles.
He relaxed his grip on her arm.
He closed his eyes and forced himself to relax his tensed body.
The dictator refuses to relax his grip on power.
His severe expression relaxed into a half-smile.

senses.definition: to allow rules, laws, etc. to become less strict

examples.x: to relax rules/restrictions/regulations/requirements
government plans to relax the licensing laws to allow round-the-clock drinking
The council has relaxed the ban on dogs in city parks.

senses.definition: to allow your attention or effort to become weaker

examples.x: You cannot afford to relax your concentration for a moment.

senses.definition: a supply of something that is available to be used in the future or when it is needed

examples.x: cash/foreign currency reserves
large oil and gas reserves
reserve funds
He discovered unexpected reserves of strength.
The country has the world's largest reserves of coal.
The company has substantial reserves of capital.

senses.definition: a piece of land that is a protected area for animals, plants, etc.

examples.x: a wildlife/forest reserve

senses.definition: an area of land in the US that is kept separate for native North Americans to live in
the quality that somebody has when they do not talk easily to other people about their ideas, feelings, etc.

examples.x: She found it difficult to make friends because of her natural reserve.
Jaime always talked to people without reserve.

senses.definition: a feeling that you do not want to accept or agree to something, etc. until you are quite sure that it is all right to do so

examples.x: Any contract should be treated with reserve until it has been checked.
She trusted him without reserve (= completely).

senses.definition: an extra player who plays in a team when one of the other players is injured or not available to play
a team that is below the level of the main team
an extra military force, etc. that is not part of a country’s regular forces, but is available to be used when needed

examples.x: the Army Reserve
the reserve police

senses.definition: the lowest price that somebody will accept for something, especially something that is sold at an auction

examples.x: The painting failed to reach to its reserve and was withdrawn from the sale.

senses.definition: the sport or activity of riding horses

examples.x: I'm taking riding lessons.
riding boots
to go riding
to go horseback riding
We went horse riding.

senses.definition: one of the three former parts of the English county of Yorkshire called the East Riding, the North Riding and the West Riding East Riding
a district that elects its own representative to a state or national government

examples.x: A by-election was called for the Ontario riding of Whitby-Oshawa.

senses.definition: legal permission to go onto or through another person’s land

examples.x: Private property—no right of way.
There is no public right of way across the fields.

senses.definition: a public path that goes through private land

examples.x: a public right of way for walkers

senses.definition: the right to drive across or into a road before another vehicle

examples.x: I had right of way at the junction.
Whose right of way is it?
roads where bikes have the right of way

senses.definition: to walk or travel around an area without any definite aim or direction

examples.x: The sheep are allowed to roam freely on this land.
Ramblers are calling for the right to roam (= the freedom to walk in open countryside) to be extended.
to roam the countryside/the streets

senses.definition: to move slowly over every part of somebody/something

examples.x: His gaze roamed over her.
Her eyes roamed over him, assessing him.
Her eyes roamed the room.

senses.definition: a type of boot with a line of small wheels attached to the bottom
a type of boot with two pairs of small wheels attached to the bottom

examples.x: a pair of roller skates

senses.definition: a park in which wild animals move around freely and are watched by visitors from their cars
a work of art that is a solid figure or object made by carving or shaping wood, stone, clay, metal, etc. make

examples.x: a marble sculpture of Venus
He collects modern sculpture.
a sculpture garden/park
a bronze/stone sculpture

senses.definition: the art of making sculptures

examples.x: the techniques of sculpture in stone
The frieze shows ancient Greek relief sculpture at its most inventive.
She trained in painting and sculpture at Columbia University.

senses.definition: to use a needle and thread to make stitches in cloth sew

examples.x: My mother taught me how to sew.
to sew by hand/machine
to sew a seam

senses.definition: to make, repair or attach something using a needle and thread

examples.x: She sews all her own clothes.
Can you sew a button on for me?
Surgeons were able to sew the finger back on.
The jewel was sewn into the lining of his coat.
The squares of fabric were all sewn neatly together.
He sewed the patch onto the back of his jeans.

senses.definition: the activity of making, repairing or decorating things made of cloth using a needle and thread

examples.x: knitting and sewing
a sewing basket
I haven’t done any sewing for a long time.

senses.definition: something that is being sewn

examples.x: a pile of sewing
She took in sewing to supplement her income.

senses.definition: the activity of going to shops and buying things or ordering them online

examples.x: to go shopping
When shall I do the shopping?
We do our shopping on Saturdays.
I do all my clothes shopping online.
a shopping basket
They go on endless shopping trips.
She is in the fashionable shopping area of London.
We do most of our grocery shopping at large supermarkets.
Customers get both online shopping convenience and highly competitive prices.

senses.definition: the things that you have bought from shops go/​go out/​be out

examples.x: to put the shopping in the car
They unpacked the shopping and put it away.

senses.definition: the sport or activity of riding on a skateboard

examples.x: a skateboarding magazine

senses.definition: a tube that you can breathe air through when you are swimming under the surface of the water
to swim under the surface of the water while breathing air through a tube (= a snorkel)
available to do what you want with rather than work

examples.x: He's studying music in his spare time.
I haven't had a spare moment this morning.

senses.definition: that is not being used or is not needed at the present time

examples.x: We've got a spare bedroom, if you'd like to stay.
I'm afraid I haven't got any spare cash.
Are there any tickets going spare (= are there any available, not being used by somebody else)?

senses.definition: kept in case you need to replace the one you usually use; extra

examples.x: a spare key/tyre
Take some spare clothes in case you get wet.

senses.definition: thin, and usually quite tall
the hobby of collecting stamps from different countries

a number puzzle with nine squares, each containing nine smaller squares, in which you have to put the numbers one to nine so that a number appears only once in each of the nine squares and in each row of nine across and down the puzzle

examples.x: He passes the time doing sudokus.
There are sudokus at four levels of difficulty.

senses.definition: a picture or pattern that is made by weaving coloured wool onto heavy cloth; the art of doing this Tapestry

examples.x: medieval tapestries
tapestry cushions
crafts such as embroidery and tapestry

senses.definition: the art of stuffing dead animals, birds and fish with a special material so that they look like living ones and can be displayed
the art of cutting bushes into shapes such as birds or animals
rails (= metal bars) that a train moves along

examples.x: railway/railroad tracks
We crossed the rail/train track.
India has thousands of miles of track.
Many branch lines were closed, and the tracks lifted.

senses.definition: a track with a number at a train station that a train arrives at or leaves from

examples.x: The train for Chicago is on track 9.

senses.definition: a piece of ground with a special surface for people, cars, etc. to have races or to drive on

examples.x: a race track
a Formula One Grand Prix track (= for motor racing)
a running track

senses.definition: the sport of running on a track

examples.x: He loves sports and participates in track and basketball.

senses.definition: a rough path or road, usually one that has not been built but that has been made by people walking there

examples.x: a muddy track through the forest
a dirt track

senses.definition: marks left by a person, an animal or a moving vehicle

examples.x: We followed the bear's tracks in the snow.

tyre tracks
The beach is criss-crossed with animal tracks.

senses.definition: the path or direction that somebody/something is moving in

examples.x: He switched tracks and went back to college.

senses.definition: a recording of one song or piece of music

examples.x: a track from their latest album

The opening track is sweet and sentimental.

senses.definition: part of a computer disk or tape that music or information can be recorded on

examples.x: a sixteen track recording studio

senses.definition: the soundtrack of a film or video

examples.x: The film is available with French and Spanish audio tracks.

senses.definition: a long, thin, straight piece of metal, wood or plastic that a curtain hangs from and moves along
a continuous belt of metal plates around the wheels of a large vehicle such as a bulldozer that allows it to move over the ground
a long line or series of marks that is left by somebody/something

examples.x: a trail of blood
tourists who leave a trail of litter everywhere they go

senses.definition: a track, sign or smell that is left behind and that can be followed, especially in hunting

examples.x: The hounds were following the fox's trail.
The police are still on the trail of the escaped prisoner.
Fortunately the trail was still warm (= clear and easy to follow).
The trail had gone cold.

senses.definition: a path through the countryside

examples.x: a trail through the forest

senses.definition: a route that is followed for a particular purpose

examples.x: a tourist trail (= of famous buildings)
politicians on the campaign trail (= travelling around to attract support)

senses.definition: to walk with an effort through something, especially water or mud

examples.x: He waded into the water to push the boat out.
Sometimes they had to wade waist-deep through mud.
The men waded ashore.
We waded across the stream.
They waded the river at a shallow point.

senses.definition: to walk or stand with no shoes or socks in shallow water in the sea, a lake, etc.
the activity of going for walks in the countryside for exercise or pleasure walking

examples.x: to go walking
walking boots
a walking holiday in Scotland
Activities on offer include walking and bird watching.
This is superb walking country.

senses.definition: the sport of walking a long distance as fast as possible without running
to walk slowly around or to a place, often without any particular sense of purpose or direction

examples.x: She wandered aimlessly around the streets.
We wandered back towards the car.
The child was found wandering the streets alone.

senses.definition: to move away from the place where you ought to be or the people you are with

examples.x: The child wandered off and got lost.
How could you let him wander off like that?
They had wandered from the path into the woods.

senses.definition: to stop being directed on something and to move without much control to other ideas, subjects, etc.

examples.x: It's easy to be distracted and let your attention wander.
Try not to let your mind wander.

examples.cf: wander away, back, to, etc. something
examples.x: Her thoughts wandered back to her youth.
Don’t wander off the subject—keep to the point.

senses.definition: to move slowly from looking at one thing to looking at another thing or in other directions

examples.x: She let her gaze wander.
His eyes wandered towards the photographs on the wall.

senses.definition: to go in a curve instead of following a straight course

examples.x: The road wanders along through the hills.

senses.definition: things made of wood in a building or room, such as doors and stairs

examples.x: The woodwork needs painting.
There were cracks in the woodwork.
elaborately/intricately carved woodwork

senses.definition: the activity or skill of making things from wood
a game consisting of letters arranged in a square, containing several hidden words that you must find
the activity of writing, in contrast to reading, speaking, etc.

examples.x: Our son’s having problems with his reading and writing (= at school).
a writing case (= containing paper, pens, etc.)
Every morning the children do writing.

senses.definition: the activity of writing books, articles, etc., especially as a job

examples.x: Only later did she discover a talent for writing.

creative writing
feminist/travel writing
He is leaving the band to concentrate on his writing.

senses.definition: books, articles, etc. in general

examples.x: The review is a brilliant piece of writing.

senses.definition: words that have been written or painted on something

examples.x: There was writing all over the desk.

senses.definition: the particular way in which somebody forms letters when they write

examples.x: Who's this from? I don't recognize the writing.

senses.definition: a group of pieces of writing, especially by a particular person or on a particular subject

examples.x: His experiences in India influenced his later writings.
the writings of Hegel
His writings on complex subjects are clear and definitive.

senses.definition: a Hindu philosophy that teaches you how to control your body and mind in the belief that you can become united with the spirit of the universe in this way
a system of exercises for your body and for controlling your breathing, used by people who want to become fitter or to relax

examples.x: He attends regular yoga classes.
I go to a yoga session on Thursdays.
She does yoga for an hour a day.

senses.definition: a place where many kinds of wild animals are kept for the public to see and where they are studied, bred (= kept in order to produce young) and protected safari park

examples.x: These lions were born in the zoo.
We saw a baby polar bear at the zoo.
a badly-run zoo

senses.definition: a fitness programme featuring Latin American dance moves, performed mainly to Latin American dance music

examples.x: Zumba is a way to exercise while also having fun.
